topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Releases on physical media

body.p: INTERSECT releases on physical media are now a ‘pull’ release instead of a ‘push’ release. If you require a physical copy, ask your local D&I License Administrator to place an order through InTouch by creating a ticket assigned to the Helpdesk SW — Distribution and Ordering. Additionally, physical media are only available for the last version of a major release cycle (typically the *.4 release).

topic.title: INTERSECT - What's new in 2022.1

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: GPU improvements

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Full GPU support for Killough hysteresis models

body.p: The Killough hysteresis model for both relative permeability and capillary pressure is now fully supported for GPU-accelerated simulations. It is expected that the performance of models containing this feature should be greatly enhanced in full GPU simulations compared to previous releases. This includes the functionality activated through the advanced fields ScaledImbibitionLookUp and ImmobileWaterImbibition for the KilloughCapPressureHysteresis node, alongside the ApplyCorrection field for the KilloughRelPermHysteresis node. This feature is activated automatically when the simulation is run on full GPU mode, and no modifications to the input data are required.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: GPU linear solver performance improvements

body.p: The GPU linear solver performance can be greatly improved by applying a good choice of coloring scheme. The different options can now be controlled by setting the LinearSolverColoring field under the GPUMgr node.

To simplify the selection of a good scheme, an AUTOMATIC coloring control has been introduced and chosen as the new default setting. By tailoring the coloring algorithm to each model, this new control can often deliver greatly improved simulation performance without any modifications to the simulation results. In most cases, the AUTOMATIC setting should provide the best performance, and it should not normally be necessary to use any other settings.

The following figure shows the normalized linear solver time, compared to the pre-2022.1 default, for a range of realistic models. Depending on the characteristics of each model, in some cases the new AUTOMATIC setting might not affect performance, while in other cases it provides a very significant improvement.

fig.title: Linear solver speed-up over previous behavior for a set of realistic models

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Multiscale sequential fully implicit method performance enhancements

body.p: The performance of the multiscale sequential fully implicit method has been improved through better accuracy and convergence. The first class of enhancements are new default settings in selected advanced fields in the TimeStepSizingControls, SequentialControls, and LinearControls nodes that reduce the need for user intervention. The second focuses on the algorithm of the multiscale pressure solver. A convergence criterion has been modified to focus on absolute cell pressure changes, particularly at cells that correspond to well connections, to avoid extra iterations that do not contribute to result accuracy. Additionally, the internal heuristics of the AMG linear solver have been tuned specifically for better performance with the multiscale pressure solver. Applied to a range of realistic models, an average performance improvement of 20% was observed in comparison with the previous version.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Water weakening compaction

body.p: A new water weakening rock compaction model introduces extra pore volume compaction dependencies on water saturation and initial rock porosity in addition to the pre-existing stress (pressure) dependence. This can be particularly important when modeling compaction in chalk reservoirs. This feature requires a multi-dimensional table of pore volume multipliers as a function of stress, initial porosity, and water saturation.
This feature also includes mechanisms to enable totally elastic rebound for pore volume to recover when pressure reversal occurs.

ul.li: RockModelWaterWeakening node description
Water weakening model section in the INTERSECT Technical Description
Compaction with water weakening workflow example in the INTERSECT User Guide illustrates the use of water weakening compaction.

fig.title: Pore volume multipliers used for a cell in an injection well for water-weakened compaction effects

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Molecular diffusion and mechanical dispersion

body.p: Molecular diffusion and mechanical dispersion have now been added for the water phase. In the INTERSECT 2021.4 release, these were only implemented for the oil and gas phases. You can use the MassTransferModel node to model mass transfer by molecular diffusion and mechanical dispersion for thermal and compositional models with component solubility in water. Among other workflows, this feature helps to model key CO2 storage features.
For more information, refer to the Diffusion chapter in the INTERSECT Technical Description and the Diffusion workflow example in the INTERSECT User Guide.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Dynamic conductive heat transfer film coefficient

body.p: A new option is available to dynamically calculate an overall heat transfer coefficient. Existing technology under the SegmentConductiveHeatTransfer node enables you to specify this coefficient as a fixed value together with a thermal contact area to model conductive heat transfer away from the well to the active grid, overburden, or from segment to segment. The new option provides the ability to set thicknesses and thermal conductivities of a pipe wall, insulation, cement, and earth so that, together with Nusselt number correlations for conductive heat transfer from the bulk flow to the inner pipe wall, an overall heat transfer coefficient can be determined. Tubing/annulus well configurations are supported. The new option gives improved accuracy for the simulation of thermal operations that are sensitive to heat transfer both into and away from the wellbore, including geothermal and steam assisted gravity drainage operations.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Solid phase for thermal simulations

body.p: Solid models have been extended to compositional thermal simulations. A new workflow example (Solids with thermal models: combustion example in the INTERSECT User Guide) illustrates the use of solid components in thermal simulations.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: IXF to CSV conversion

body.p: A new utility, IXF2CSV, enables you to convert an existing IXF case into an input deck consisting of CSV files with many frequently used fields. CSV files are easier to modify using external tools such as Microsoft Excel.

For further information, in the INTERSECT User Guide refer to Automatic IXF to CSV generation workflow in Appendix 7 for a full list of supported IXF parameters and nodes and the Using the Automatic IXF2CSV generation workflow example to see the utility in use.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Minimum network period for network solves

body.p: This functionality enables you to control the frequency of network solves so that they are executed less often compared to other Field Management (FM) logic. This improves performance for simulations where network balancing actions are deemed to be particularly expensive. Existing network balancing constraints are carried forward at the coupling points where network solves are skipped. This functionality is different from the coupling setting in the Period field in the CouplingProperties node because new coupling time points are not created.

A common use case for this workflow is solving the network at a pre-defined frequency (for example, at the start of every month) and the rest of the FM logic at newton-iteration level (iteratively lagged) to improve simulation performance. Using the UseNetworkPeriod field enables certain networks in a simulation to be selected to solve at the defined network period frequency with the remaining networks being solved at the actual FM frequency.

For more information, refer to the MinNetworkPeriod field in the CouplingProperties node, the UseNetworkPeriod field in the NetworkBalanceAction node, and the Coupling compositional reservoirs with different components workflow example in the INTERSECT User Guide.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Extended TestWellAction node with region property monitoring

body.p: New fields have been added to the TestWellAction node. This node checks whether closed wells can flow and opens them if so. The frequency of those tests is controlled by the TestingTimeInterval field. To be more representative of field operations, you can now restrict the triggering of these tests by monitoring region property changes around selected wells using the RegionProperty, RegionChange, and RegionTolerance fields. You can choose the type of region used to monitor those changes in a similar way to the create_regions_around_wells() command from the RegionMgr node, which means that hop-based regions, distance-based regions, and flow-based regions are supported. Using region property monitoring with TestWellAction is restricted to wells and cannot be use with completions. The RegionChange field enables the tracking of negative change, positive change, or changes in any direction in the region property.

You can use this functionality to avoid testing wells that are intermittently opened and immediately shut owing to economic actions (or pressure limit shut-offs) that cause significant intermittent flows in the simulation and, in certain cases, performance degradation.

fig.title: Well-based regions to capture and track regional properties (such as pressure or saturation) before deciding to test a well for flow

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Additional properties in OBSH files

body.p: The following brine and polymer components concentration properties have been added to the list of data mnemonics recognized by OBSH files:
The component name is appended with double quotes in square brackets: COMPONENT_EQUIV_CONC["NaCl"]

After INTERSECT loads one of these properties from the OBSH file, it is assigned to the corresponding well. INTERSECT automatically generates an external fluid source for each well with concentration inputs. The Composition field in the FluidSourceExternal node is then populated with the historical data. The external fluid source created is assigned to the corresponding water injector well under the InjectionStream field in the Well node.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Pre-set reporting level for minimal output

body.p: A new ReportMgr node has been introduced in Field Management that currently has a field to allow all reporting, including restarts, to be controlled according to predefined sets. A 'minimal' preset is introduced in this release, and configures the simulation output to a basic set. The purpose of this feature is to provide a simple mechanism to override existing report controls, achieve improved simulation performance, and reduce disk space use.

You can activate this feature by setting the ReportingLevel field to MINIMAL. This has the effect of turning off all 3D reporting and restart output and reduces the amount of reports written to the PRT file by using the minimum VerbosityLevel setting. Summary (line plot) reporting is not disabled but is restricted to basic field and well properties. All input specifications of the different outputs are ignored and instead the output is entirely controlled by the ReportingLevel field setting.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Report well connection transmissibility and permeability thickness

body.p: Two new properties, TRANSMISSIBILITY (alias CONFAC) and INTEGRATED_PERMEABILITY (alias CONKH), have been added to the Recurrent3DReport node. These properties are used to output the transmissibility and the permeability thickness at the connection level. With these added report properties, you can now easily quality check the well completions and see how well to cell transmissibility changes with time.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: P/Z report for field and regions

body.p: A new property, PRESSURE_GAS_Z_WEIGHTED (alias PRGZ), has been added to the FieldProperties (report label FPRGZ) and RegionProperties (report label RPRGZ) nodes under the XYPlotSummaryReport node. This property is used to report P/Z (gas) average value weighted by gas content of blocks at surface conditions. The Migrator also now supports the migration of FRPGZ and RPRGZ summary vectors from ECLIPSE to INTERSECT.

fig.title: Field, pressure/Z (gas) weighted by gas content

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Report cumulative lift gas injection

body.p: In addition to the LIFT_GAS_INJECTION_RATE that you could already report as XYPlotSummaryReport output on wells, groups, and the field, you can now report the equivalent cumulatives using the new LIFT_GAS_INJECTION_CUML property ID.

topic.title: Extension to print file reporting

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: State for region family (or cell selection family) table

body.p: An extra column showing the total pore volume at reference conditions has been added to this table. The new column, named 'Reference Pore Volume', appears after the 'Dynamic Pore Volume' column. This column is output when VerbosityLevel is set to 2 or higher for the RegionFamily, CellSelectionFamily, or RegionFamilyMgr nodes.

The column named 'Average Pressure' has been renamed to 'Average Pressure HCPV weighted' to explain that the values it shows are calculated using the hydrocarbon pore volume weighting method. This distinguishes the existing column from the new column that follows it named 'Average Pressure PV weighted' where the values are calculated using pore volume weighting. This new column (Average Pressure PV weighted) is output when VerbosityLevel is set to 2 or higher for the RegionFamily, CellSelectionFamily, or RegionFamilyMgr nodes.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Surface fluid moles in place table and wet gas volume in place table

body.p: INTERSECT can now report the surface fluid moles in place for total hydrocarbon and the wet gas volume of the total hydrocarbon in place (which is equivalent to the ECLIPSE 300 'Hydrocarbon surface volume' report). These reports are output when the VerbosityLevel is 3 or higher for the RegionFamily, CellSelectionFamily, or RegionFamilyMgr nodes.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Wet gas volume in place table

body.p: INTERSECT now allows the reporting of wet gas volume in place for each component in addition to the moles and mass in place. This is reported in the 'Wet Gas Volume in place' table, which follows the 'Mass in place' table in the PRT file. For each region in the chosen region family or cell selection, this table shows the wet gas volume in place for each component present. This table is only output if the VerbosityLevel field for the appropriate RegionFamily, CellSelectionFamily, or the parent RegionFamilyMgr is set to 3 or higher.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Updated Intel MPI version

body.p: A new version of Intel MPI (v2021.4) is now included. This version is recommended for use with modern hardware configurations.
The previous version (v2018.1) is also included. This version is retained for use with legacy hardware configurations.

On Windows, select which version you want to install in the Install Menu dialog box. On Linux, both versions are installed side-by-side. When multiple MPI versions are installed, ECLRUN will use the most recent compatible version by default. If you want to change this version selection behavior, refer to the INTERSECT Installation and Deployment Guide.
body.note: The new version is not a direct replacement for the old version because the underlying fabric has changed. The environment variables for configuring the new version are different and you must revisit these if you decide to upgrade.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Behavioral changes

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Changes in simulation

ul.li: The way residual oil saturation (SOR) is handled (that is, removed from the fluid composition before, and restored after, some computations) has been made consistent in 2022.1. Previously, the amounts removed and restored could be different in cases where the current oil saturation had fallen below the SOR in a cell. This change prevents occasional unphysical behavior such as water saturation dropping below connate in models which use this SOR feature. If you wish to go back to the previous behavior you can specify set_int_option(name="pre_2022.1_sor" value=1) in the OptionMgr node.

From 2022.1 any equilibration regions containing only gas and water phases initially will have their saturation and capillary pressure relationship modeled as a gas-oil-water system instead of a gas-water system. This resolves problems initializing 3 phase systems when oil-water and oil-gas capillary pressures are defined in regions containing no initial oil and the initial water saturation is user-defined. The change results in slightly different saturations above the gas-water contact, and therefore different initial fluid in place volumes. You can revert to the previous behavior by specifying set_int_option(name=”pre_2022.1_gw_init” value=1) in the OptionMgr node.

The coloring schemes for the GPU linear solver have been modified to improve performance. This modification should not change the results and is expected to give equivalent or better performance in all cases. If adverse changes are encountered, the previous coloring scheme can be activated by specifying set_int_option(name="pre_2022.1_multicolor_reorder" value=1)) in the OptionMgr node.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Changes in well model

ul.li: Grid independent wells' deviation data are handled within the same coordinate system as that of the coarse grid from 2022.1. Previously, well deviation data was shifted by coarse grid origin before well-to-cell connections were determined. The change is to remove this translation by grid origin, so that well deviations and the coarse grid are defined consistently. Consequently, discrepancies in simulation results may be observed in models whose coarse grid's origin is not trivial. If you wish to go back to the previous behavior you can specify set_int_option(name="pre_2022_1_grid_independent_wells_deviation" value=1) in the OptionMgr node.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Changes in field management

ul.li: From 2022.1, each HistoricalDataControl is only applied to the wells that are explicitly listed in its Wells field (or all wells if that list is left as, or set to, an empty list). This was the documented behavior before this release but, in practice, the content of that field was ignored and the control was applied to all wells. To recover the previous behavior, you can set the Wells field to an empty list (that is, Wells=[]).

p.u: Format of CSV file referred to in CSVControl

ul.li: From 2022.1, the file referred to in CSVControl nodes is read following the format described in RFC 4180 as used by Excel. Specifically, embedded quotes (") and backslashes (\) in quoted fields are encoded as '""' and '\' instead of '\"' and '\\' previously. If you wish to go back to the previous behavior you can specify set_int_option(name="pre_2022.1_csv_format" value=1) in the OptionMgr node.

A bug was introduced in the 2021.2 release which meant that well inflow performance relationship (IPR) curves were not calculated as frequently as had been requested. This occasionally led to issues in coupled workflows where wells were shut unexpectedly. This has been fixed in the current release so that these IPR curves are now calculated at the frequency specified in the RecalculateFullIPRsOnResolveNetwork field of the CombinedNetworkBalanceAction node. At the same time, the default value of that field has been changed from NEVER to ON_CHOP_FAILURE to improve stability.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Changes in reporting

body.p: This is some text to push the ul further.
etc
etc
etc
etc

ul.li: The label used for 3D reporting of SOLID_RES_VOLUME_IN_PLACE in Petrel has been changed from RDIPR to SDPIR.
The label used for 3D reporting of SOLID_VOLUME_FRACTION in Petrel has been changed from SOLDVF to SVF.
A new label SOL_DEN has been added for 3D reporting of SOLID_RESERVOIR_DENSITY in Petrel.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Changes in the Migrator

p.u: Correct Temperature value when CO2SOL creates an extra PVT region

ul.li: From 2022.1, when an EOS compositional fluid model is defined in the .DATA file, and an extra PVTNUM fluid model is created, the Migrator now ensures the RTEMP values are assigned to the compositional fluid models used for the water properties in addition to those for the hydrocarbon properties. Hence, there are two compositional fluid models written to the .ixf for each "real" fluid model when migrated, with the temperature values for both (EOSNUM and PVTNUM) models being set. Previously the water property models were assigned default temperature values (212 degF). In practice, this temperature value is not used, however, if a user wishes to achieve the previous behavior, the temperature value in the .ixf file of the migrated deck will need to be modified and set to 212 degF.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Changes in multiscale extension

p.u: Multiscale SFI solver default settings changes

ul.li:
Starting 2022.1, simulations where TimeDiscretizationMethod is set as MULTISCALE_SFI have tuned heuristics in setting up the AMG solver. Also, improvements to the convergence criteria of nonlinear and linear pressure solvers have been made, aiming to save unnecessary iterations. The timestep, linear and sequential controls were adjusted for better multiscale pressure solver performance. Though not recommended, previous behavior can be recovered by specifying in the OptionMgr node:
set_int_option(name=" mg_use_heuristics" value=0)
set_int_option(name="ms-improve-pressure-linear-solver" value=0)
set_int_option(name="ms-pressure-use-new-convergence" value=0)
And changing the following parameters:
TimeStepSizingControls.TimeStepCutDecreaseFactor=0.125
SequentialControls.PostSmootherIters=1
LinearControls.LaggedRelativeNorm=TRUE

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Licensing and installation

body.p: The simulator checks at run time for valid licenses. This release requires date based versioned licenses.
When using the Schlumberger License Server, please note that it must be v2020 or later. Licenses that may be required are:

row.entry: Core INTERSECT runtime license enabling simulation. The core license also includes the ix_fm and ix_tools features.
Enables the generation of INTERSECT input models from ECLIPSE keywords or from the Petrel Reservoir Engineering user interface.
Simulation upgrade license – required when using “–sim-ul” command line option. The license also includes ix_fm and ix_tools.
ECLIPSE runtime license enabling simulation – required instead of ix_base when using “–sim-ul” command line option.

Enables the coupling of INTERSECT Field Management to multiple reservoirs and network simulators such as GAP. For an integrated project with N1 INTERSECT reservoir models and N2 surface network models, the number of ix_coupler licenses required is (N1+N2–1). Coupling to Schlumberger applications is excluded from this calculation.
This license also enables coupling of INTERSECT to an external 3rd party controller.

Enables INTERSECT to simultaneously run multiple similar realizations of the same model for a lower license cost.
ix_mr licensed models are produced by Petrel, which signs them to prevent further modification of the model.
For each running model sharing the same unique identifier one ix_mr license is required, but all models will share a single ix_fm, ix_base, thermal and/ or ix_coupler license. ix_ucparallel licenses are not shared across the models.
Simulator license enabling Compositional fluid simulations.
INTERSECT license enabling Thermal simulations – alternative to sim_thermal license.
INTERSECT license enabling Compositional fluid simulations – alternative to sim_compositional license.

Enables INTERSECT parallel computing option. An ix_cluster_parallel license is required for any model running more ways parallel than the limit of 48. This number is calculated by multiplying the number of processes by the number of threads per process in hybrid parallel runs.

Enables INTERSECT unlimited parallel computing option. An ix_ucparallel license is required for any model running more ways parallel than the limit of 128. This number is calculated by multiplying the number of processes by the number of threads per process in hybrid parallel runs.
Enables INTERSECT Multiscale Sequential Fully Implicit (SFI) method.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Platform availability

body.p: This release of the INTERSECT simulator is supported on the following platforms.

ul.li: Windows 64 bit desktop - Windows 10 (x64) with Intel MPI.
Windows HPC OS with MSMPI. Windows Server 2012 R2 HPC update 2 (x64)
Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 7 update 9 (x86_64) with Intel MPI and Platform MPI.
Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 update 4 (x86_64) with Intel MPI.
CentOS Linux Server 7 update 9 (x86_64) with Intel MPI and Platform MPI.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Feature compatibility and known issues

body.p: The INTERSECT and ECLIPSE feature compatibility section in the INTERSECT Migrator User Guide provides information that may be useful when comparing the results of INTERSECT with those from other simulators. The list of supported ECLIPSE keywords is provided in the INTERSECT Migrator User Guide.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Licensing error code -5008

body.p: You might experience an issue when running INTERSECT if the Schlumberger Licensing environment variable uses a mixture of local and remote license servers and the local server is defined without a port number.

When local and remote license servers are combined in the incorrect format, it will often result in a "-5008" error which indicates that the system has detected an invalid license file path. This occurs when a path is not in the expected format port@host or there is an inappropriate use of comma (,) characters in the license file path.
To resolve this issue, make sure that there is always a port number before each host name. For example, if @localhost is present, change it to 27000@localhost or similar.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Aquifer modeling

ul.li: Modeling of tracers with aquifers is not available.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Equilibration

ul.li: When comparing INTERSECT simulation results with those from other simulators, you must compare the initial fluid in place calculated by the simulator with the reference simulator, before the dynamic simulation is started. If there are differences, then candidates for investigation include rock compaction, end-point scaling, capillary pressures, initial fluid compositions, pressures, and temperatures.

Critical fluid initialization is not currently supported when the COMPVD keyword is present. The COMPVD keyword is, however, supported for bubble-point and dew-point fluid initialization. For critical fluid initialization, the PSAT property is reported as zero.

More detailed information on the INTERSECT initialization and equilibration may be output from the simulator, by increasing the verbosity level of the Equilibrium Manager. Refer to the EquilibriumMgr node in the INTERSECT User Guide for more information.

Some differences with ECLIPSE may be observed in the initialization of models using the brine option. This is because the underlying formulation in INTERSECT is based on mole fraction rather than concentration variables, and a nonlinear conversion is required from the input concentration values.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Fluid modeling

ul.li: Some of the algorithms for calculating thermal properties differ from those used in ECLIPSE Thermal. To obtain a closer match in results, set the ThermalProperties field on the FluidMgr node to "ECLIPSE" or "ECLIPSE_IAPWS97". For more information, refer to Thermal simulation in the INTERSECT Technical Description.
The second order term of the fluid enthalpy equations is different between INTERSECT and ECLIPSE. It affects the simulation results only if the coefficients are nonzero.
The reduced phase formulation cannot currently be used with the variable API black oil fluid model. A validation error will occur if you try to use these features together.
Use of Langmuir isotherms with dual porosity systems is currently not supported.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Gridding and parallel simulation

ul.li: Unlike ECLIPSE, the INTERSECT simulator has no restrictions on forming a 1D or 2D Cartesian partitioning of the grid into domains to be simulated by separate processor in a parallel simulation. By default, the simulator treats all grids as unstructured and, therefore, its parallel partitioning algorithm is completely automatic. The parallel partitions can be viewed in a 3D viewer by selecting the grid property 'PART'. The partitioning may be complicated with unstructured grids, or grids with (possibly nested) local grid refinements.

Traditional Cartesian partitioning is not recommended, but you can enable it by first specifying the structure of the grid and then the IJK cuts. For more information, refer to the StructuredInfo and CartesianPartition nodes in the INTERSECT User Guide.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Grid independent wells

ul.li: Grid independent wells cannot be connected to cells that have been coarsened. If grid independent wells and coarsening are defined, INTERSECT issues a warning. It is responsibility of the user to prevent a grid independent well to intersect a coarsened region of the grid.
Grid independent wells can be defined only for Pillar grids. INTERSECT issues an error if grid independent wells are defined for a different type of grid.

The grid independent wells workflow can deal with cells with non-planar faces, but for efficiency it assumes the cells are convex. This could lead to a slightly inaccurate connection calculation if a well crosses a non-convex area of the cell. In this case, a refinement of the well deviation will overcome this issue.
The grid independent wells workflow doesn't currently support multisegment wells.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Grid property editing

ul.li: Now grid property editing is possible even when geometry has not been supplied to INTERSECT. There are limitations to what can be edited depending on workflow. For example, this option is not yet compatible with the use of MPFA. Refer to Grid property editing in the INTERSECT Technical Description.

There is a known issue in parallel when TRANSMISSIBILITY_I, TRANSMISSIBILITY_J or TRANSMISSIBILITY_K edits are applied to LGR host cells when those host cells are in the halo of a parallel partition region.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Migrator

ul.li: The --process-grid-edits option that disables the grid transmissibility calculation within INTERSECT is now deprecated, and will be withdrawn in the next release.

The old --eclipse-init command line option is incompatible with the default grid edits migration workflow. Therefore, setting this option implies the --process-grid-edits option. This is now deprecated, and will be withdrawn in the next release.

In thermal cases with the old Migrator workflow (now the --process-grid-edits option), the use of keyword MULTIPLY with TRANX, TRANY or TRANZ is currently not allowed. An error is issued in such cases.
The FREQ mnemonic in the RPTRST keyword when specified in the SCHEDULE section generates 3D visualization files (*.FXXX) in INTERSECT at different timesteps from ECLIPSE.
CONLENST and CONLENEN values in the RFT files are incorrect for the Migrator workflow.

For the WELSPECS and WELSPECL keywords, if the Pressure table number is defaulted, then the WellBoreFluidModel is no longer explicitly set in the resulting WellDef node, and the default fluid model is used.
MULTX/Y/Z- support is the same as Eclipse (i.e. support for MULTX etc. in EDIT section only in E100 style decks, MULTPV is supported for both styles).

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Petrel to INTERSECT workflow

ul.li: INTERSECT models, created using Field Management, write the INTERSECT IXF files directly, rather than using the ECLIPSE Migrator. By using INTERSECT grid edits, this results in greatly improved export performance for large models.
If the reservoir simulation grid has LGRs created in a GSG file and also in the IXF file, the combined LGRs for this case cannot be visualized when imported back into Petrel.

In a Petrel workflow, the generated WellToCellConnections nodes do not define the TrueVerticalDepth field. In this case, INTERSECT takes the Z coordinate of the center of the connected cell as the true vertical depth of the center of the connection.
Grid independent wells always accurately calculate the true vertical depth of the center of the connections. This could lead to differences in results if a Petrel exported well is replaced by a grid independent well with the same deviation and completions defined in terms of start and stop measured depth.

If a grid independent well is added to a native Petrel case, the Y coordinates of the well deviation must be flipped (in other words, the sign must be changed). This is due to the difference in coordinate systems used by Petrel and INTERSECT.
When a well trajectory file is exported by Petrel, the Y coordinate is automatically flipped to account for this difference. If grid independent wells are added to a Petrel case externally, it is the responsibility of the user to flip the Y coordinate of the deviation.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Reporting

ul.li: INTERSECT uses a different method than ECLIPSE for calculating inter-region phase flows for reporting purposes. It takes the molar rates for all components and feeds them to the configured separator for the fluid in place report. This may give different results from ECLIPSE.

For consistency with pressure reporting, INTERSECT calculates well TEMPERATURE as the (pore volume weighted) average of connected cell temperatures on all wells (regardless of whether they are injector or producer, open or shut). This differs from ECLIPSE 300 which generally reports WTEMP as
flowing bottom hole temperature for flowing wells,
average reservoir temperature for non-flowing producers,
injected fluid temperature for non-flowing injectors. Note that INTERSECT also reports BOTTOM_HOLE_TEMPERATURE for flowing wells.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Rock physics

ul.li: INTERSECT supports both the Killough and Carlson relative permeability hysteresis methods, but not that of Jargon, which is available in ECLIPSE 300.
To increase simulator stability, a validation check has been added to ensure that critical and maximum saturations for each cell in the simulation grid are separated by at least 1E-06.

A validation check ensures that saturation endpoints are defined in the correct order:
S(connate) < S(critical) < S(maximum)
This validation may not be present in other simulators. In addition, the simulator checks that the relative permeability at maximum saturation is higher than the critical saturation value.

The definition and calculation method for a capillary number may differ from other simulators, depending on the feature in which it is used. For models other than the Whitson gas condensate capillary number dependent relative permeability model, INTERSECT does not scale the capillary number by porosity, saturation, or immiscible relative permeability.

The precise way in which endpoint scaling is implemented in INTERSECT may differ from other simulators. For example, ECLIPSE uses a special treatment of each of the intervals between the connate, critical, associated critical and maximum saturations, which is not implemented in INTERSECT.

If the scanning curves in Killough relative permeability hysteresis become too steep, INTERSECT has a new option to look up the primary drainage curve. Enable this option by setting SteepScanningCurveAsPrimaryDrainage = TRUE on the RelPermHysteresis node. This may improve performance for some models with steep saturation curves.

The use of nonvolatile residual oil saturation with the near critical relative permeability mixing feature can result in nonzero mobility of the oil which can lead to convergence problems. This can be mitigated in some cases by disabling the near critical relative permeability mixing feature.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Solution of the equations

body.p: INTERSECT has the ability to simulate in a variety of implicitness formulations: fully implicit, IMPSAT, IMPES and two adaptive implicit (AIM) schemes: AIM_IMPES and AIM_IMPSAT.

ul.li: The non-fully implicit time-discretization formulations (IMPES and IMPSAT) typically suffer from small timesteps and low simulator performance. Their adaptive implicit counterparts AIM_IMPES and AIM_IMPSAT are recommended instead.

In adaptive implicit (AIM) simulations, especially in parallel, the timestep size may be severely restricted by the maximum fraction of implicit cells (refer to the AimCriteria node in the INTERSECT User Guide). In this case, it is recommended to increase the maximum fraction of implicit cells from the default 10% up to a maximum of 50%.

The IMPSAT formulation should only be used in a compositional simulation where there are more than two hydrocarbon components. In two-component compositional or black oil simulations, the specification of IMPSAT results in a warning and the conversion of the simulation to IMPES mode.

In some cases, the timestep size may be limited by the time truncation error (TTE). INTERSECT and ECLIPSE use different formulae to evaluate the TTE. If the timestep size is being severely restricted by the TTE it is recommended that the value of this limit be increased from the default (0.1). For more details, refer to the TimeStepSizingControls node in the INTERSECT User Guide.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Well modeling

ul.li: When the simulator cannot find a valid flowing solution for a well (for example, if the reservoir pressure is below the minimum BHP limit for a producer), it shuts the well along with all its connections, regardless of the setting item 9 in the WELSPECS keyword. This differs from ECLIPSE, which performs a surface shut-in under these circumstances if item 9 in the WELSPECS keyword is set to STOP.

The solution of heaters in INTERSECT is different to the approach used in ECLIPSE. Internally, a heater with multiple cells attached to it is treated as a whole rather than the method used by ECLIPSE that solves each cell individually. This is an improvement on the ECLIPSE method, however it is computationally more difficult and currently suffers from known convergence issues. If you encounter convergence issues, the workaround is to split the heater into individual cells, which yields closer results to ECLIPSE.
When using the variable API facility, the convergence behavior of the simulation may be improved by banning crossflow in wells.

INTERSECT reports the actual steam quality (WSQU) at the bottomhole depth in the well while ECLIPSE Thermal reports the user-defined value. The actual steam quality is slightly different depending, for example, on well pressure and crossflow.

The calculation of voidage rate is performed by transforming the wellstream fluid to the average conditions over the field or a specified region. In black oil simulations, this calculation differs between ECLIPSE 300 and ECLIPSE 100. In ECLIPSE 300, the fluid properties are calculated at the average hydrocarbon pressure in the field or region. However, in ECLIPSE 100 the solution gas-oil ratio (Rs) of the oil phase is also capped to not exceed the average Rs of the field or region. The calculation in INTERSECT by default, follows the ECLIPSE 300 method, and may therefore give different voidage rates than ECLIPSE 100 when the oil in the field or region is significantly undersaturated and the wellstream gas-oil ratio is significantly higher than the average field or region Rs. Compatibility with the ECLIPSE 100 method can be improved by setting the LimitByAverageRsRv field in the ResVolConditions node.
The drift flux flow model in multisegment wells is not supported in thermal simulations.

In runs using the hysteresis option, hysteresis does not apply in rock models that are specific to well-to-cell connections. If a well-to-cell connection has a specific rock model assigned to it (see the field RockModelName in the WellSaturationFunctions node), the saturation table defined in the DrainageSaturationFunction field in the RockModelDefinition for this rock model is used for both drainage and imbibition processes. The COMPIMB feature in ECLIPSE has not yet been implemented in INTERSECT, so at present it is not possible to provide an imbibition table for use in rock models specific to well-to-cell connections.

topic.title: Well optimizers

ul.li: Only Field Management groups constraints for the same fluid phase as the optimizer target fluid phase will be honored. A warning message is given where group constraints are incompatible with the well optimizer
The streamline optimizer only supports deferral and control of water breakthrough.

topic.domains: (topic task) (topic concept) (topic concept glossentry) (topic concept glossgroup) (topic reference) (topic troubleshooting++task) (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
topic.title: Third party software and hardware

ul.li: Simulation Launcher requires .NET Framework 4.5 or later to function.

If you are running serially without using the queuing system on the Microsoft HPC platform, you need to disable the AffinityOnWindows configuration option. Refer to the ECLRUN User Guide for instructions.

You may encounter problems running INTERSECT with Platform MPI using a version of LSF earlier than 9.1. When this occurs, the simulation finishes as usual, however LSF behaves as if the simulation is still running and prevents other jobs from starting. You can either run the Intel MPI version of INTERSECT (the default version), or upgrade LSF. You must use LSF 9.1 or later.

When running on certain OS and NAS storage hardware configurations, INTERSECT can experience intermittent file system errors when attempting to clean very large directories of previous summary result data. INTERSECT displays a warning message when this occurs and attempts to retry cleaning the directories. If it cannot clean out the files, the following error message is displayed. WARNING Filesystem error attempting to write summary report files. Retrying now. Actual error is: boost::filesystem::basic_directory_iterator increment: Too many levels of symbolic links: "file location" ERROR Grid "" has already been written.
The workaround is to manually clean out the summary report files from previous runs before launching the simulation.

INTERSECT supports several different job schedulers. Each has its limitations and requirements. Full documentation on Scheduler Integration can be found on the DVD in the 3rdParty directory. Only Windows HPC, LSF and PBS support the scheduling of MR jobs. Running MR jobs with UGE or on a Windows Workstation with no additional scheduling, may not achieve the best utilization of resources.However, please note that

On some machine setups, ECLRUN may have problems parsing the JOB ID when a submission has been made to UGE. If this happens, the following modification to the ECLRUN script may help.
Find the line: return fullCmd, fullCmd, self.JobResponseScraper(result_pattern, 1)
Change it to: return fullCmd, fullCmd, self.JobResponseScraper(result_pattern)

Very basic Torque functionality is enabled in ECLRUN but it is not supported and is not particularly effective. For example, the scheduling of jobs based on licenses is not enabled. Torque 2.X or 5.X has been found to be more stable than 4.X with ECLRUN.

You must set the LD_LIBRARY_PATH variable in ECLRUN when you are using the eclrun=c plmpi command. If the LD_LIBRARY_PATH variable is not set the eclrun=c plmpi command does not work. You can set the LD_LIBRARY_PATH variable to an empty value, for example export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=".

If the disk system containing the simulation model is remote to the simulation processor(s), and therefore has a limited transfer bandwidth, you may experience reduced simulation performance. This may be a result of simulation database logging. This logging can be disabled by using the command-line option --no_msgdb=true.

topic.title: Documentation

body.p:
In some rare circumstances it has been observed that the INTERSECT manuals do not appear by default in the Manuals section of the Simulation Launcher after installation. If this occurs, you can add it by following the steps below:
On the Tools menu, click New.
Select New Program, and then add the INTERSECT manuals.

topic.title: Installer

ul.li: Uninstalling the release also removes the Simulation Launcher, even if other versions of the simulators are installed.
If you are installing to a network mapped drive, then you must run the install as an Administrator, or the installer does not recognize the drive.
